The Story of King Kuru
“Then again, when I was
in the supreme city of Indapatta,
a king named Dhananjaya,

analyzed: kusale  kaliṅga raṭṭha visayā  brāhmaṇāḥ upagan śu ma
translated: skilled in the ten (arts of) goodness.🔽The brahmins of the Kaliṅga country🔽came to me;
they asked me for an elephant,
a boon considered to be grain.
‘The country is not prosperous,
the famine is great, the people are starving;
give us the supreme elephant,
the blue one, the one with the colour of antimony.’
‘When a beggar has come to me,
it is not right to refuse him;
may my vow not be broken,
I will give the great elephant.’
Having seized the elephant by the trunk,
in precious bronze vessels;
having sprinkled water on his hand,
I gave the elephant to the brahmins.

analyzed: tassa nāge padinnamhi  amaccāḥ etat abravu
translated: When the elephant was given away,🔽the ministers said this to me:
‘Why do you give away the supreme elephant,
to those who ask for it?
The boon is endowed with grain,
the supreme victor in battle;
when the elephant is given away,
what will the kingdom do for you?’
‘He might give me his whole kingdom,🔽or even his own body,
but omniscience is dear to me,
therefore I gave the elephant.’
The Story of the King of Kuru, the third.
